                    • −
                    • +
                    • aashaik chinnam rupesh ram • 23 days ago

                      The moment you append extern to a variable you are telling compiler that,
                      hey compiler we are using a variable known as var, that has already been globally defined somewhere in the entire program (including other files).

                      In GCC linux it gives only warning, below. But it gives the output 10
                      warning: ‘var’ initialized and declared ‘extern’
                      extern int var = 0;
                      ^

                      Where as in a modern compiler like Clang, it straight away given below error
                      error: 'extern' variable has an initializer [-Werror,-Wextern-initializer]
                      extern int var = 10;

                      I think clang is more appropriate compiler because, understand when do we use extern. We use it in two cases:-
                      1. When we want to just declare a variable with no memory allocation
                      2. When we want to tell the compiler that a particular variable is already a global variable and is defined else where and we are using it here in this file.
                      ( Generally we do this in case of multiple files and a variable of one file defined at global level is being used in some other file )

                      So, as far as it is obvious that Clang compiler does not expect an initialiser when we append extern keyword to a variable. ( or else it throws an error ). Which pretty much sums up the two cases above.

                              A local variable always shadows the visibility of a global variable.
                              Coming to the topic of extern int b; in the second line, you have just declared it but not defined, so technically no error here.

                                                • +
                                                • aashaik Abhishek Tyagi • 17 days ago

                                                  First thing is, please understand that extern keyword is used in multi C files programming environment.
                                                  Consider the below case, I want to use a variable of first file in second file.

                                                   
                                                  /* file1.c */ 
                                                  #include<stdio.h>
                                                  int var = 10;


                                                  /* file2.c */ 
                                                  #include<stdio.h>
                                                  extern int var;

                                                  int main(void){
                                                  var = var +1; 
                                                  printf("%d",var);
                                                  return 0;
                                                  }

                                                  Output: 11

                                                  I wish this should clear your confusion.
                                                  If you are still unclear, please feel free to ask.

                                                                                              int main()
                                                                                              {
                                                                                              int a=10;
                                                                                              a=5;
                                                                                              printf(" %d",a);

                                                                                              • 1

                                                                                              • Share ›
                                                                                                • −
                                                                                                • +
                                                                                                • aashaik SARAVANAN. K.S • 23 days ago

                                                                                                  I dis-agree with you.
                                                                                                  int a = 10;
                                                                                                  here you have done declaration + definition ( allocation of memory along with value 10 into the memory )
                                                                                                  storing this value into memory is known as initialisation.

                                                                                                  a = 5; here you have re-initialised.
                                                                                                  You neither did re-declaration nor re-definition ( allocation of a new memory address )

                                                                                                  In the same memory address allocated in the first step, you have just changed the value stored in that memory location. So it is simply re-initialisation.

                                                                                                  Consider below.

                                                                                                  int a =10;
                                                                                                  int a;
                                                                                                  The above is known as re-declaration. Re-declaration is not allowed in C and it is big error.

                                                                                                                              If there is no extern keyword you will not be able to use a variable defined in a file, in another file.
                                                                                                                              In case of functions all functions are extern by default.

                                                                                                                                    I am having problems here,

                                                                                                                                    when I compile and run this program it works as expected:
                                                                                                                                    #include<stdio.h>
                                                                                                                                    extern int i;
                                                                                                                                    int main(){
                                                                                                                                    int i=9;
                                                                                                                                    printf("%d\n",i);
                                                                                                                                    return 0;
                                                                                                                                    }

                                                                                                                                    but when I push extern inside main() it throws error,

                                                                                                                                    #include<stdio.h>

                                                                                                                                    int main()
                                                                                                                                    {
                                                                                                                                    extern int i;
                                                                                                                                    int i=9;
                                                                                                                                    printf("%d\n",i);
                                                                                                                                    return 0;
                                                                                                                                    }

                                                                                                                                      see more

                                                                                                                                      • +
                                                                                                                                      • Wolf firetrail • 7 months ago

                                                                                                                                        #include<stdio.h>
                                                                                                                                        extern int i;
                                                                                                                                        int main(){
                                                                                                                                        int i=9;
                                                                                                                                        printf("%d\n",i);
                                                                                                                                        return 0;
                                                                                                                                        }
                                                                                                                                        here you are declaring the variable i( extern int i) but not defining it,its ok if you not define it. Then comes the local variable i(inside main int i=9) where you are declaring and defining it, hence value 9 is printed as local variable has higher precedence.

                                                                                                                                        #include<stdio.h>

                                                                                                                                        int main()
                                                                                                                                        {
                                                                                                                                        extern int i;
                                                                                                                                        int i=9;
                                                                                                                                        printf("%d\n",i);
                                                                                                                                        return 0;
                                                                                                                                        }

                                                                                                                                        here since extern is used within main and in the next line(int i=9) you are re-declaring i, which leads to error.As you cant declare the same variable twice in a function.
                                                                                                                                        1. extern is used inside a function when the global variable is declared after the function and you have to use that variable.
                                                                                                                                        ex:
                                                                                                                                        #include<stdio.h>

                                                                                                                                        int main()
                                                                                                                                        {
                                                                                                                                        extern int i;
                                                                                                                                        printf("%d\n",i);
                                                                                                                                        return 0;
                                                                                                                                        }
                                                                                                                                        int i;

                                                                                                                                        hope you got the answer. correct me if i am wrong.

                                                                                                                                                      • +
                                                                                                                                                      • aashaik aravind • 23 days ago

                                                                                                                                                        here by saying extern int i; you have just declared a variable ( no memory allocated )
                                                                                                                                                        in the next line by saying i = 20;
                                                                                                                                                        You are trying to allocate a value 20 to i which was never given any memory location to store the value.

                                                                                                                                                        Another interesting thing is..

                                                                                                                                                        extern int i;
                                                                                                                                                        int i = 20;

                                                                                                                                                        the above will also, not work. As, you are trying to re-declare the i for the second time.

                                                                                                                                                        Actually your case is correct, but only when i is already defined globally somewhere in the entire program.

                                                                                                                                                          • PK Rock aravind • 8 months ago

                                                                                                                                                            compile time error:undefined reference to `i'

                                                                                                                                                            why because your declaring the i variable but the variable is not defined anywhere. eg...if your declaring any variable using extern keyword means it must and should define somewhere otherwise compiler will generate error.
                                                                                                                                                            that's why you will get linker error....(GCC compiler linux 32 bit)
